titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Program, Department Chronological Correspondence Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Program, Department Chronological Correspondence Files FA549

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-11-01 00:57:13 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Program, Department Chronological Correspondence Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains department correspondence sent by Ford Foundation staff in the International Affairs Program as well as reports, grant status reports, and grant program action forms. The correspondence is typically notices of grant approvals or grant declinations on projects related to international law and the environment, international peace and security, international human rights, international economics and development, U.S. foreign policy, and relations with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

The dates on each folder refer to the dates on the weekly correspondence control forms. The forms list names/initials of relevant personnel, the date individual staff reviewed the correspondence, and the date the weekly correspondence was collected. The weekly correspondence forms were used to collate correspondence at the end of each week. If a folder in this collection is called "Chrons, 1991 February 8-15," then you can expect to find correspondence, grant action forms, and reports sent and reviewed between February 1-15 (the week before the first date in the folder title). If there is no specific day mentioned in the folder title only the month (ex. 1992 April), then the correspondence control forms are missing. The correspondence control forms are not always accurate and correspondence from previous weeks and months may be found in neighboring folders.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series:
The series refer to the change of program area title that occured during Foundation restructuring in the early 1980s. The folders within the collection are arranged chronologically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For International Affairs Program, Department Chronological Correspondence Files from April-December 1990, see Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Division, Program Staff Files (FA548), Series I.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Segment One: International Activities of the Ford Foundation: An Overview

The Foundation's aspiration to become a national and international philanthropy for the advancement of human welfare was first formally expressed in the seminal 1949 report of the Gaither Study Committee, Report of the Study for the Ford Foundation on Policy and Program (RAC Library, call letters 361.7 GAI ), which was commissioned by the Board of Trustees to chart the Foundation's future. Foundation Trustees launched Ford's international grantmaking activities in 1950 when they approved the committee's report and its embrace of peace, democracy, and freedom. Since then, the Foundation has tackled these goals using a variety of strategies and responding to changing contexts, from the Cold War to the 1989 fall of the Berlin Wall and beyond.

Toward the Foundation's aspirational goal, "the establishment of peace", its international activities have comprised a wide range of conceptual approaches and focus areas. These include international affairs, international studies, international understanding, arms control and disarmament, international law, international economic concerns, and overseas development in nearly every region of the world. Three distinct periods emerge for the international grantmaking defined by external contextual changes and internal changes in Foundation leadership and structures: the expansion era of 1950-1965; the transition and restructuring years of 1966-1988; and the post-1989 shift away from Cold War dichotomies. During each of the distinct historical periods the consistent objectives were: 1) to ensure freedom and democracy in developed countries; 2) to foster education and international understanding in all countries; and 3) to contribute to the social, economic, and political development of less developed countries.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: A portion of this collection was transferred to RAC in 2012 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2012:034. These chron files (January 1991-August 1996) were processed shortly after arriving at the RAC. Another set of material was transferred to the RAC by the Ford Foundation in 2019 and ingested by RAC as parts of Accessions 2019:012, 2019:028, and 2019:046. These materials (Chrons, 1978-1990) were added to the existing collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of chronologically arranged memoranda and correspondence that was collected weekly from European and International Affairs staff. The correspondence refers to grant proposals, grant evaluations, research competitions for grant funding, meetings, trips, conferences, program reviews, and administrative matters. The correspondence was written by the following staff (in approximate order names appear in the series): Francis (Frank) X. Sutton, Peter Ruof, Felice D. Gaer, Enid C. B. Schoettle, Bruce L. Bushey, Ruth D. Carter, Crauford Goodwin, Michael Nacht, Wendy Gatof, Jill Newsom, Ms. Serrano, Ms. Watts, Ms. Edwards, Veronica Bermudez, Adrianne Grunberg, Nelly Rivera-Marrero, Ms. Bullard, Ms. Resnick, and Charlotte Van Deusen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of chronologically arranged memoranda and correspondence that was collected weekly from the International Affairs Program staff. The corresponence refers to grant proposals, grant evaluations, research competitions for grant funding, meetings, trips, conferences, program reviews, and administrative matters. Correspondence from the following International Affairs Program staff (in approximate order names appear in the series): Enid C. B. Schoettle, Paul Balaran, Thomas O. Bayard, Gary G. Sick, Laurice H. Sarraf, Schwartz, Adrianne Grunberg, Nichol, Rossi, Walsh, Joyce Dickson, Debra Lamb, Ann and Harry Cavanaugh, Bikales, Nelson, Brian Urquhart, Janice Rhea, Stanley J. Heginbotham, Thomas Trebat, Karel Vosskuhler, Seamus O'Cleireacain, Shepard Forman, Margo Picken, Joseph Schull, Delilah King, Mahnaz Isapahani, Geoffrey Wiseman, Miriam Aukerman, Larry Cox, Lavinia Baumhoff, Christine Wing, Bernard Wasow, Marion Pendleton, Matthew Findlay, Mary DeCaro, and Edwin Rekosh.
